And so I did bring an animal

88.text:
about snake bites, and
why people fear snakes.

Snakes evoke probably the most
extreme emotional response

94.text: of any of our education animals.

96.text:
And a lot of it's
hyped on TV, folklore,

100.text:
back in the Old

But snakes do a good job of
ridding your garden of pests,

but there are some issues
with venomous snakes

Now one thing I do want
to put out a disclaimer,

the information that we're

has to do with snakes
in the Memphis area.

If you get outside
the Memphis area,

119.text:
particularly other parts of
the world, the attributes

122.text:
of venomous snakes can be
different in important ways.

127.text:
But to put it into context,
about 45,000 people

130.text:
in the United States get
bitten by snakes every year,

132.text: you know over a huge country.

135.text:
Of those, probably six
or seven thousand people

138.text:
are bitten by venomous
snakes, and of those,

145.text:
but still it gives you an
idea of the scale of it.

When talking to the
students about snakes,

152.text:
people, the first thing
the students will say is,

Well, of course, anything

but you get a show of hands

have been bitten by

you get a big show
of hands, right?

No one in the room typically
has ever been bitten by a snake

or knows anyone, but still,
people fear, and rightly so,

Memphis, as far as
venomous snakes go,

177.text: is not too bad of a place to be.

We have four types
of venomous snakes

180.text: that are possible in our area.

Two of 'em are rattlesnakes,
this is a Timber Rattlesnake,

But there really aren't
a lot of rattlesnakes

in the Memphis area, they

and that sort of stuff,
and that's good news,

because of the snake deaths
in the United States,

202.text:
the five or six people
who do die of snake bites,

Common in our area,
though, are Copperheads

209.text:
and Water Moccasins, and
I brought a freeze dried,

212.text:
this is an adult Copperhead,
and I brought a mount

216.text:
that shows some different
types of snakes,

Copperheads are probably
the most frequent source

224.text:
of snake bites and
that sort of stuff,

226.text:
but people rarely
die of their bites.

Cottonmouths may chase you,
they live near water and such,

231.text:
but as far as people gardening
and all that sort of stuff

233.text:
in Memphis, provided you
don't have a pond or swamp

236.text:
in your backyard, a
Copperhead is probably the one

239.text: you're most likely to run into.

242.text:
But even though, I'm
getting ready to give you

245.text:
some information that if you
can tell this information,

247.text:
you're too close, but a couple
tips to tell the difference

252.text:
one of the most
characteristic in our area

255.text:
have to do with
looking at the heads.

258.text:
Venomous snakes have elliptical
pupils, like cat eyes,

261.text:
and non-venomous snakes
have round pupils,

266.text:
Venomous snakes heads are
arrow-shaped, and the reason

269.text:
they're arrow-shaped,
actually their venom glands

273.text:
and venom's a modified
form of saliva.

276.text:
If you could look under
their tail, you'd see

279.text:
under the anal plate, venomous
snakes have a single line

284.text:
of scales, whereas non-venomous
have a double line.

288.text:
And if you are lucky
enough in my parlance,

291.text:
to find a snake shed in
your backyard, you can tell

294.text:
if it's venomous or non-venomous
by looking at the tail.

299.text:
- And that gives you an
idea of what to look around,

301.text:
but if you can tell these
thing, you may be too close.

I did bring an
animal ambassador,

306.text:
this is a Speckled King
Snake, this is the most common

There's seven sub-species
of king snakes, this is one,

They're called
king snakes, one of

317.text:
their favorite foods
are other snakes.

They're said to be immune
to the venom, and they have

special techniques of

of venomous snakes to keep

But like other snakes, they
are secretive, they hang out

in the same sort of areas
and they're well adapted

334.text:
for hunting, they also
eat lizards, mice,

337.text: a wide variety of other things.

340.text:
- Oh yeah, all
snakes help us out.

In fact, one of the things that
attract snakes into the area

345.text:
if you have mice and
that sort of stuff,

they pick up on that and
come in search of food.

But if you run into
a snake in the wild,

353.text:
rather than getting in
close to look at the eyes

356.text:
or the tail, your best
bet is to step back slowly

360.text:
three feet, and typically,
the snake will scamper away.

Snakes are attracted to
motion and that sort of stuff,

366.text:
but any case, in the wild,
you wanna put some distance

368.text:
between yourself and the
snake, however if you do see

375.text:
a snake, like I said,
it's common sense,

378.text:
Of the people that
get bitten by snakes,

380.text:
40 to 50 percent of them
actually picked the snake up.

384.text:
- And they're honestly
surprised when they get bit.

387.text:
- But unfortunately,
if you do get bitten,

391.text:
you wanna take some
certain precautions.

394.text:
Even a non-venomous snake
bite, you can get lacerations

397.text:
from the teeth, they
have needle-sharp teeth

399.text:
that point backwards,
so if you pull,

402.text:
you can actually injure
the snake if you pull out,

405.text:
but if you get bitten by a
venomous snake, the first thing

408.text:
to do is to get
away from the snake.

410.text:
Again, that should
be common sense.

414.text:
- But if you get bitten by a
snake, thanks to all the hype

416.text:
on TV, books, so forth and so
on, people the first symptom

421.text:
of snake bite is just
overwhelming fear,
and it's not caused

424.text:
by the bite of the
venom, it's caused

426.text:
by your over-emotional response
to being bitten by a snake.

430.text:
And then if you do
unfortunately, get bitten

433.text:
by a venomous snake,
your rapid pulse rate

435.text:
and all like that, from gettin'
excited about the situation,

440.text:
But you wanna get
away from the snake,

441.text:
see if you can identify
it, but the main thing

443.text:
is to get away from
it, to elevate the part

447.text:
that gets bitten, around
the area of your heart.

450.text:
You wanna remove any rings or
watches, because you probably

454.text:
will swell up if
it's not a dry bite.

456.text:
And by the way, 25 percent
of even venomous snake bites,

459.text:
particularly adults, they
don't use all their venom,

462.text:
they have a good
amount of control.

464.text:
If they're hunting for food,
they just use a little,

466.text:
but unfortunately, if
they're being defensive,

467.text:
if you step on them or
they think you're going to

470.text:
corner them, they
will use more venom.

473.text:
But you elevate it,
you wrap it loosely

476.text:
and get medical attention
just as quickly as you can.

479.text:
One thing, I learned this
in camp and it was fun,

482.text:
about this, but we've
been taught over time

485.text:
that you're supposed to
put an X on it with razors,

488.text:
suck the venom out,
apply a tourniquet,

490.text:
and that sort of
stuff, and we now know

492.text:
that all that's the
wrong thing to do.

495.text:
But again, the most
important thing

497.text:
is to seek medical
attention and tell them

500.text:
what you know about
the experience,

502.text:
and let the trained
professionals do
the rest on that.

504.text:
- So sucking out the
venom and that stuff

506.text: that we see on TV is not--

507.text:
- No, no, but
anything about snakes,

509.text:
particularly snake bites
are serious, and should be

511.text:
taken seriously, but it's
not a death sentence,

514.text:
except for just a handful
of cases that come up.

we appreciate that

And folks, I don't know if
they really wanna go out there

556.text:
and water their plants,
so can we help 'em out,

560.text:
- Yeah, and something that
they can do right away,

562.text:
one of the first things
that you can do if you

564.text:
haven't already
done this is mulch.

567.text:
Simply putting some mulch
on the ground will help

569.text:
retain moisture in the
soil and it will also keep

574.text:
the temperature more stable
for the roots of your plants.

577.text:
It can also help
when it degrades,

582.text:
it will add nutrients
to the soil.

585.text:
And of course, it prevents
that crust, because sometimes

588.text:
when the water hits the
soil surface, it puts

590.text:
a little crust layer on
the soil, and then when

593.text:
it rains again, that
layer is so tight

595.text:
that it lets water run off
rather than soak in the ground,

598.text:
and mulch helps
prevent all of that,

601.text: so mulching is a great idea.

603.text:
Another thing that you
can do to help yourself

605.text:
and your plants is to
water either in the morning

610.text:
or in the evening
before the sun sets.

612.text:
You've got to let the flowers
and the leaves dry off

617.text:
before the sun sets,
because that's gonna set

620.text:
a perfect scenario for
diseases to set in,

623.text:
so you wanna prevent that,
but watering in the morning

626.text:
and watering in the evening
is a nicer time of day,

629.text:
it's cooler, morning is the
best if you can do that,

633.text:
but you know with people's
hectic schedules and trying

635.text:
to get to work, as long as
you water in the evening

637.text:
before the sun sets so that
the leaves can dry off,

640.text: that's a good time to water.

642.text:
Another thing you can do is
plant groups of plants together

646.text:
that require the same types
of water requirements.

650.text:
And how will you know you've
done that, well, if you have

653.text:
a container or an area
that you planted a whole

656.text:
different kinds of plants
in there, you water 'em,

659.text:
and then some of them
die, well they don't like

662.text:
that much water or you
don't water 'em enough

665.text:
and some of 'em live, and
some of 'em didn't live

669.text:
Well you'll know that
the water requirements

672.text:
for that particular plant that
didn't live is not conducive

676.text:
to the other plants that
you've planted it with.

680.text:
Good examples for some dry
kind of flowers and plants

686.text:
that can take drought would
be like your Dusty Millers

690.text:
and your Lantanas,
also there's some grass

696.text:
it does really well
with dry areas.

700.text:
Then of course for larger
trees, you've got your hollies,

704.text:
anything with, you gotta
think thick leaved,

707.text:
anything that has got
a thick leaf on it

709.text:
like your Indian Hawthornes
and your Magnolias

712.text:
and your Hollies, those
all can take some drought

716.text:
because they have
thicker leaves on them.

720.text:
A lot of herbs can do that
too, you think of your sages

723.text:
and your oreganos and your
rosemaries and the bay leaf,

730.text:
all of those can take
more drought situation

732.text:
because they have
larger, thicker leaves.

736.text:
Let's see, also, Memphis
area is very humid.

744.text:
and I don't like putting water
in the air to water things.

750.text:
If you can use soaker hoses,
that would be the best thing

753.text:
that you can do, because
it puts water right on

756.text:
the root zone where
the plants need it.

759.text:
And you will save yourself
money and time by having

762.text:
soaker hoses, and just all
you have to do is go out

765.text:
and hook up a soaker hose,
and come back in and then

767.text:
30 minutes later go out and
check, and maybe give it

770.text:
another 30 minutes or
not, and you're done,

773.text:
and you don't have to stand
there and water anything.

777.text:
So if you can use some
kind of system that puts

780.text:
as large of particles of
water as possible out,

785.text:
you're not gonna be evaporating
a lot of it in the heat,

787.text:
so you're not gonna make
Memphis any more humid

789.text:
than it already is, but yes,
and you'll save yourself money

793.text:
in the long run because you
won't have to use so much water.

797.text:
And now if you have some
time, when you are planting,

804.text:
I highly recommend adding
organic matter to the soil

808.text:
because soils here in this
area are very small in size,

813.text:
and they are very tightly
held together, there's not

816.text:
a lot of air and water movement
and space for the roots

820.text:
to even grow, so if you amend
the soil, organic matter

825.text:
will break that up and give
you larger areas to hold water,

833.text:
So you're gonna do a
better job for yourself,

837.text:
save yourself some time in
the long run and not use

840.text:
as much water if you have
water that stays in the ground

845.text:
a lot longer, and organic
matter will help you do that.
